coredata.dc:title: Photoemission, inverse photoemission, and ab initio SCF investigations of the electronic structure of polyimide
coredata.dc:creator: Meyer, H.M.
Wagener, T.J.
Weaver, J.H.
Feyereisen, M.W.
Almlöf, J.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Inverse photoemission was combined with direct photoemission for a unique investigation of clean films of poly(N,N′-bis(phenoxyphenyl)pyromellitimide). Experimental results for the valence and conduction states extending from 22 eV below the Fermi level to 10 eV above the Fermi level are presented. The occupied and empty states of PMDA-ODA have also been investigated with ab initio self-consistent field molecular orbital calculations, and comparison with experimental results to identify the origin of spectral features shows excellent agreement.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 164, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 22 December 1989 PHOTOEMISSLON, INVERSE PHOTOEMISSION, AND AB INITIO SCF INVESTIGATIONS OF THE ELECTRONIC STRUCTURE OF POLYIMIDE H.M. MEYER III, T.J. WAGENER, J.H. WEAVER Department of Chemical Engineering and Materials Science. University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, USA M.W. FEYEREISEN and J. ALMLOF Department of Chemistry and Minnesota Supercompuier In5titute, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, USA Received 21 August 1989; in final form 3 October 1989 Inverse photoemission was combined with direct photoemission for a unique investigation of clean films of poly(N,N - bis(phenoxyphenyl)pyromellitimide). Experimental results for the valence and conduction states extending from 22 eV below the Fermi level to 10 eV above the Fermi level are presented. The occupied and empty states of PMDA-ODA have also been investigated with ab initio self-consistent field molecular orbital calculations, and comparison with experimental results to iden- tify the origin of spectral features shows excellent agreement. 1. Introduction A complete description of polymer bonding re- quires detailed experimental and theoretical inves- tigations of the occupied and empty electronic states. This information provides the basis for understand- ing polymer interactions with metallic and semicon- ducting materials [1 9] - The past 15 years have pro- duced a wealth of information on the valence electronic structure of adsorbed organic films and the surfaces of thin film polymers [10 13]. Photoelec- tron spectroscopy (PES) has been frequently used in experimental studies of the electronic structure be- cause it reveals the occupied electron energies [14,151. Information about the conduction (unoc- cupied) electronic stales of polymers has typically been obtained from spectroscopies that exploit elec- tronic excitations, notably optical absorption spec- troscopy, near-edge X-ray absorption fine structure (N EXAFS), and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS). These techniques provide valuable infor- mation but are indirect probes of the unoccupied one- electron levels since they measure differences be- tween electronic states. In contrast, inverse photo- electron spectroscopy (IPES) directly probes the un- occupied electronic states of a material and is complementary of PES [14]. Although IPES has been used to study organic adsorbates on noble metal sub- strates [16 l 8], it has never before been used to ex- amine the electronic structure of polymers or organic solids. In this Letter we compare photoemission and in- verse photoemission results with ab initio self-con- sistent field molecular orbital (SCF-MO) calcula- tions of the electronic structure of polyimide. We have chosen poly(N,N -bis(phenoxyphenyl)pyro- mellitimide) (PMDA-ODA) since similarly pre- pared films have been studied previously by a num- ber of techniques [19 24]. MO calculations have often been used to identify features of PES spectra of polymers [9 131. We demonstrate that comple- mentary information can be obtained by using cal- culated anionic states to identify features of IPES spectra. The success of this approach for PMDA- ODA indicates the feasibility of using IPES to di- rectly probe the unoccupied electronic states of other polymer systems. 2. Experimental For IPES, incident electrons enter states of energy 527 0009-26 14/89/$ 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland) Volume 164, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 22 December 1989 E~, referenced to the Fermi level of the spectrometer, before decaying radiatively to empty states of lower energy E~, emitting photons of energy ht = E Ef. In our spectrometer, a 1 X 5 mm sheet beam of mono- energetic electrons (E~= 14 to 22 eV) was directed at the sample surface, and the distribution of emitted photons of energy hv was measured with a resolution of 0.3 0.6 eV (see ref. [25] for details). The depth of the surface probed, as defined by the kinetic en- ergy of the incident electron E,, is approximately 3A = 87 A, where A is the electron escape length [261. Polyimide degradation observed during exposure to the electron beam (resulting in spectral features that were diminished and broadened [27]) was mini- mized by using low beam currents (100 ~tA cm 2) and moving to a fresh area of the polymer surface every 5 min. Each IPES spectrum therefore repre- sents an average of data collected from five different spots. For the XPS measurements, a monochroma- tized Al Ku X-ray beam with a 1000 im spot size was focused onto the sample surface, and the photo- electron kinetic energies were determined with a Surface Science Instruments hemispherical analyzer, referenced to the Fermi energy of the spectrometer. The Fermi energy, EF, was known from calibration studies of metallic gold and by examining the low binding energy cut-off of a Ta clip in contact with the spectrometer and the polyimide sample (see ref. [28] for further details). The polyimide samples were prepared in situ by thermally imidizing polyamic acid films which had been spun onto Au- and Al-coated silicon wafers. This procedure resulted in clean, fully imidized films with thicknesses of 200 A. Completion of the imidi- zation process was ascertained by analysis of the C, O, and N 1 s core levels in terms of proper binding energies and lineshapes [29]. These films were suf- ficiently thin that charging problems were negligible. The XPS and IPES studies used identically prepared PMDA-ODA samples. 3. Calculations The model for the PMDA-ODA monomer unit, shown at the top of fig. 1, was constructed with ge- ometry parameters obtained from X-ray diffraction studies of the model compound 4,4 -bis(phtal- imide)-diphenyl ether [30]. It has recently been shown that the valence band density of states is quite insensitive to rotation about the N ~ bond [23,24] (Takahashi et al. [30] obtained a torsional angle of 600 in the solid state whereas Hahn et al. [9] sug- gested a value of 00. Silverman et al. [31] concluded that the torsional angle should be <60 .) We have performed calculations using torsional angles of 0 and 90 , but in the following discuss only the 0 re- sults. The modification of the valence and conduc- tion band states at the 90 angle was minimal and does not change the conclusions reported. Minimi- zation of the energy led to a tilt of the ODA frag- ments by 50 (trans) with respect to the PMDA plane. The dimer and trimer were constructed by joining monomer units in an all-trans fashion with an O bond angle of 105 . In all cases, the polymer chain was terminated with OH groups at both ends. Ab initio SCF calculations were carried out for the monomer, dimer, and trimer using a basis [32] of four s- and two p-type primitive Gaussians for the heavy elements C, N, and O, and two s-type for H, contracted to a minimal basis by means of a general contraction scheme. Experience has demonstrated that this basis, although quite small, gives orbital energies and other features of the electronic struc- ture in surprisingly good agreement with larger basis sets [33 J. All calculations were performed on the ETA- 10 computer at the Minnesota Supercomputer Center using the direct SCF code DISCO [34]. Cal- culations were carried out for neutral molecules as well as for the four lowest negative ion states of each species. Electron affinities were obtained as the dif- ference between the SCF energies for the ionic and neutral states. Relaxation effects (i.e. the difference between virtual orbital energies and electron affini- ties given by ionic state calculations) are 0.2 0.5 eV and do not diminish as the molecule becomes larger. This is an indication that the states are very localized in nature, a notion which is borne out by inspection of the MO coefficients. The orbital energies obtained for the dimer and trimer equalled those of the mon- omer to within 0.1 eV, suggesting that delocalization of the states is unimportant. 528 Volume 164, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 22 December 1989 4. Results and discussion Fig. 1 shows XPS results for fully cured PMDA- ODA. Major features al ~5.5, 10.5, 14.5, 18, and 21 eV below EF are in general agreement with previous photoemission results for polyimide [4,9]. Shown above the XPS valence bands in fig. 1 are our SCF- MO results as generated by summing a series of Gaussians associated with the 40 highest occupied molecular orbitals of the monomer. Each Gaussian was assigned unit height and a full-width-at-half- maximum (fwhm) of 1.5 eV to simulate experi- mental results. To facilitate comparison, the calcu- lated spectrum was adjusted by expanding the en- ergy scale by a factor of 1.5 so that the spacing between the features near 1 8 and 6 eV equalled the experimental value. The energy zero was rigidly shifted to align the central features at 10.7 eV. The Fig. 1. Valence electronic States of PMDA-ODA within 22 eV of the Fermi level. The experimental XPS curve was obtained with a 200 A thick PMDA-ODA film. The theoretical curve was gen- erated by summing Gaussians of equal height and fwhm and spaced according to the orbital eigcnvalues obtained from the calculations. The energy scale for the calculated spectrum was expanded and rigidly shifted to facilitate comparison with the experimental spectrum, as discussed in the text. The inset shows the PMDA-ODA monomer, and the axis labels refer to the ori- entation used in our SCF-MO calculations. rigid shift can be rationalized because the Fermi level position in the gap is pinned by localized energy states associated with intrinsic impurities or irregularities in the PMDA-ODA structure. The dilation may be due in part to the geometric model used to simulate PMDA-ODA and in part to solid state relaxation ef- fects for the experimental data. With these adjust- ments, the agreement between the calculated and ex- perimental spectra is excellent. The coefficients of the eigenvectors make it pos- sible to identify the predominant orbital parentage of each feature in the simulated spectrum. Features centered at 6.2 and 8.2 eV are associated with C N It orbitals and C C n (ODA) orbitais, respectively. C C it (PMDA), N lone pair, and O lone pair or- bitais contribute to the large feature centered at 10.7 cV and extending to 13.4 eV. The feature at 15.4 eV is comprised of C C it (ODA), C H cs (ODA) and C O it bonds from both ODA and PMDA, while C-C it (PMDA), C-H n (ODA), and C-O it bonds are related to the feature at 18.5 eV. Finally C H ~ (PMDA) and C O it bonds make up the feature at 21 eV. There is general agreement between the assign- ments outlined above and previous theoretical re- sults. Hahn et al. [9] have carried out SCF-MO cal- culations on separate PMDA and ODA moieties and have compared them to experimental UPS results. While there is overall agreement in the assignment of the MOs, we differ in the location of the N and O lone pair orbitaIs (we place them at 10 eV rather than 5 eV) and with the assignment of the feature at 15 eV (we attribute it to C C it (ODA), C H ~ (ODA) and C-O it (ODA, PMDA) instead of C 2s orbitais). These differences may reflect the different models used for the two calculations. Previously, we have compared the XPS spectrum of fig. ito a den- sity of states calculated by Bredas and Clarke [35] that produced very narrow bands (widths <0.25 eV for the highest 35 occupied bands, implying strongly localized electronic states). Broadening the calcu- lated bands by 2 eV led to good agreement (fig. 5 of ref. [29]). The excellent agreement with the XPS data and the general agreement with previous stud- ies suggest that our SCF-MO calculations should rep- resent the unoccupied states quite well. At the left of fig. 2 we show IPES data for fully cured PMDA-ODA taken at incident electron ener o o PMDA-ODA ~ Valence Bands a..- 04 040 n~ ~ n- ~ b ~ ~ b S ~~- i ~ t 0 00 08~ /~_i ~ ~i:-t; u, ~1- .u) a) C -1 C o (J, (n E ai o o -C u- 20 16 2 Binding Energy (eV) 529 Volume 164, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 22 December 1919 (J) C o >. u-, C w C I-l C o o u- Fig. 2. Inverse photoelectron spectra revealing the empty states for 200 A films of PMDA-ODA obtained at a variety of incident electron energies, E,, and normalized to the electron beam cur- rent and total acquisition time. The inset compares IPES results at E, = 16 and 20 eV with empty states results from our SCF-MO calculation and NEXAFS experiments for PMDA-ODA 1191. One to one correspondence between IPES data, the calculation, and the NEXAFS data is obtained by aligning the features closest to EF. gies of l4<E~<22 eV. The data have been normal- ized to total acquisition time and incident electron beam current, with each curve representing an av- erage of spectra taken on freshly exposed spots. The Fermi energy was determined from the emission on- set for Pd metal in electrical contact with the poly- irnide sample. Each spectrum shows rich structure with a large peak at n~4.5 eV and features located at 3, and 6.5 eV. Moreover, the peak intensities vary strongly with E~. In general, the photon emis- sion yield depends on the electron-capture cross sec- tion and the radiative transition probability between initial and final states. Since the electron capture cross section does not vary significantly over the range of incident electron energies used in this study, we con- clude that the variation of the peak intensities prob- ably reflects variations in oscillator strength. It is quite remarkable that such strong modulation occurs over such closely spaced electron energies. In the inset of fig. 2 we show the IPES experi- mental curves for E~= 16 and 20 eV and the distri- bution of empty states obtained from our SCF-MO calculations (top curve). The calculated spectrum was generated by assigning a Gaussian of unit height to the 12 lowest unoccupied molecular orbitais and summing them, after broadening with a width com- parable to our spectrometer resolution. The simu- lated spectrum was shifted 0.8 eV away from EF to align the large features ai 4.5 eV. This accounts for the pinning position of the Fermi level in the gap by localized electronic states, as mentioned above. As for the valence bands, we note excellent agreement between calculation and experiment. The orbital parentage of the unoccupied states fea- tures can be identified by examining the coefficients of the calculated eigenvectors. The peak closest to EF at ~2 eV is predominantly a C C it~ (PMDA) or- bitai with some C N it and C O it~ (PMDA) char- acter. The feature at 3 eV reflects a single orbital derived from C O it character of the carbonyl groups with some C C it (PMDA) character. The domi- nant feature at 4.5 eV is derived from five closely spaced orbitals, two are solely C C it~ (ODA) or- bitals, two are admixtures of C C n (ODA) and C N it orbitals, and one is made up of C N n and C O it (PMDA) orbitais. The broad peak at 6.5 eV arises from levels which are predominantly C O it (PMDA) with some C-N it and C-C it (PMDA) admixture. The calculated peak at 8.5 eV is made up of two orbitals of C O it 1 (PMDA) and C N it character. At the right of fig. 2 we also compare our IPES re- sults to recent NEXAFS results obtained for PM DA- ODA by Jordan-Sweet et al. [19]. The NEXAFS spectrum shows excitation in the photon energy range 284 to 290 eV, i.e. originating from C Is states. Nearly one-to-one correspondence between the experimen- tal peaks is seen when the lowest energy NEXAFS feature is aligned with the lowest energy feature of our IPES data. With a few exceptions, the assign- ment of features by Jordan-Sweet et al. is similar to our assignments [19]. Indeed, this is gratifying be- cause the assignments of the NEXAFS data were made by comparing the PMDA-ODA spectrum to simpler polymers, i.e. polymers containing a single 0~EF 4 ~1~ -F 4 8 12 Energy Relative to EF (eV) 530 Volume 164, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 22 December 1919 organic functional group. We assign the feature at 3 eV above EF to largely C O it (PMDA) and C C it1 (PMDA) states while the NEXAFS structure was assigned to a C C it~ orbital of the ODA phenyl ring. Also, the peak at 8.5 eV in the empty state calcula- tions was assigned to largely C O it (PMDA) char- acter, while Jordan-Sweet et al. assigned it to C C it orbitals of both the PMDA and ODA phenyl rings [19]. Comparison of IPES data with NEXAFS data shows that these techniques give similar results for the unoccupied molecular electronic states. There are, however, ways in which the IPES data differ from those obtained with NEXAFS. First, the NEXAFS features are dependent on both the C is levels as well as the empty states and give information about the unoccupied levels with different weighting. Second, the location of the empty states with respect to the Fermi level is less certain for a NEXAFS spectrum because of interactions of the it and n* states with the core hole created by photon absorption. IPES has a distinct advantage in the sensitivity of the struc- ture to the incident electron energy. This shall be of particular value in more detailed studies of the empty states of complex molecular systems. IPES does suf- fer from problems related to electron-beam-induced damage of the polymer surface, but we have found that these effects can be avoided for PMDA-ODA. In summary, we have shown that inverse photo- electron spectroscopy makes it possible to investi- gate the unoccupied electronic structure of thin poly- mer films. The interpretation of IPES empty state data and XPS occupied state data for PMDA-ODA was guided by theoretical electronic structure models. The application of IPES to the investigation of the empty states of PMDA-ODA indicates that this tech- nique can be extended to other polymer systems. Fi- nally, identification of the IPES features will allow us to assess the changes to the PMDA-ODA unoc- cupied molecular states as a function of reactive metal deposition, and such studies are currently underway. head.ce:title: Photoemission, inverse photoemission, and ab initio SCF investigations of the electronic structure of polyimide

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Inverse photoemission was combined with direct photoemission for a unique investigation of clean films of poly(N,N′-bis(phenoxyphenyl)pyromellitimide). Experimental results for the valence and conduction states extending from 22 eV below the Fermi level to 10 eV above the Fermi level are presented. The occupied and empty states of PMDA-ODA have also been investigated with ab initio self-consistent field molecular orbital calculations, and comparison with experimental results to identify the origin of spectral features shows excellent agreement.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Photon, electron, and ion probes of polymer structure and properties
